[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-dkg/src/pcs/traits.rs] [Function: open()] [Side-channel leakage] Does open() leak information about polynomial coefficients through timing, memory access patterns, or branch behavior during proof generation? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-dkg/src/pcs/traits.rs] [Function: batch_open()] [Empty batch] Can an attacker call batch_open() with empty polynomial and blinding vectors to generate trivial batch proofs that always verify, bypassing security checks? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-dkg/src/pcs/traits.rs] [Function: batch_open()] [Length mismatch] Does batch_open() validate that polys and rs (if Some) have matching lengths, or can length mismatches cause out-of-bounds access, panics, or use of wrong blinding factors? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-dkg/src/pcs/traits.rs] [Function: batch_open()] [Challenge reuse] Since all polynomials share the same challenge vector, can an attacker exploit challenge reuse to create cross-polynomial attacks that forge batch proofs? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-dkg/src/pcs/traits.rs] [Function: batch_open()] [Batching attack] Can an attacker include one honest polynomial and multiple malicious polynomials in batch_open(), exploiting batch verification to hide individual proof forgeries? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-dkg/src/pcs/traits.rs] [Function: batch_open()] [Randomness aggregation] If batch_open() aggregates blinding factors incorrectly, can an attacker exploit aggregation to cancel out randomness and break the hiding property? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-dkg/src/pcs/traits.rs] [Function: batch_open()] [Mixed None/Some blinding] If rs is Some but contains None elements, does batch_open() handle mixed blinding correctly, or can this cause inconsistent proofs or verification failures? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-dkg/src/pcs/traits.rs] [Function: batch_open()] [Transcript state] Does batch_open() update transcript state consistently for all polynomials, or can an attacker exploit transcript inconsistency to forge batch proofs? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-dkg/src/pcs/traits.rs] [Function: batch_open()] [Large batches] Can an attacker provide extremely large polynomial batches (e.g., millions of polynomials) to cause memory exhaustion, slow verification, or integer overflow in batch aggregation? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-dkg/src/pcs/traits.rs] [Function: batch_open()] [Polynomial order] Does the order of polynomials in the batch affect proof generation, and can an attacker exploit ordering to create proofs that verify but don't correspond to claimed commitments? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-dkg/src/pcs/traits.rs] [Function: batch_open()] [Commitment key ownership] Does batch_open() take ownership of CommitmentKey instead of borrowing, potentially causing issues if the key is needed for subsequent operations? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-dkg/src/pcs/traits.rs] [Function: verify()] [Proof forgery] Can an attacker construct a proof that passes verify() but corresponds to a different polynomial evaluation than claimed, breaking soundness? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-dkg/src/pcs/traits.rs] [Function: verify()] [Challenge validation] Does verify() check that the challenge vector dimensions are correct, or can wrong-sized challenges cause verification to incorrectly accept/reject proofs? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-dkg/src/pcs/traits.rs] [Function: verify()] [Transcript consistency] Does verify() rebuild the Fiat-Shamir transcript identically to open(), or can transcript state differences cause legitimate proofs to be rejected or forged proofs to be accepted? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-dkg/src/pcs/traits.rs] [Function: verify()] [Commitment-eval mismatch] Can an attacker provide a commitment C1, evaluation e1, and proof from different commitment C2 such that verify() incorrectly accepts? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-dkg/src/pcs/traits.rs] [Function: verify()] [Zero proof] Does verify() accept the zero proof (empty/trivial proof), which could allow attackers to claim arbitrary evaluations without valid openings? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-dkg/src/pcs/traits.rs] [Function: verify()] [Special evaluation values] Can an attacker exploit special evaluation values (0, field order, infinity) to make verify() accept forged proofs due to degenerate verification equations? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-dkg/src/pcs/traits.rs] [Function: verify()] [Batch verification bypass] If verify() is called individually on batch proofs, does it properly validate each opening, or can batch proofs bypass individual verification checks? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-dkg/src/pcs/traits.rs] [Function: verify()] [Return type] Does verify() return Result to allow implementations to propagate errors, but can panics in implementations cause validator crashes during DKG verification? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-dkg/src/pcs/traits.rs] [Function: verify()] [Verification key validation] Does verify() validate that the VerificationKey is well-formed and corresponds to valid cryptographic parameters, or can malformed keys cause incorrect verification? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-dkg/src/pcs/traits.rs] [Function: verify()] [Side-channel timing] Does verify() run in constant time regardless of proof validity, or can timing differences leak information about whether proofs are valid, enabling timing attacks? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-dkg/src/pcs/traits.rs] [Function: random_witness()] [Weak RNG] If random_witness() is called with a weak or predictable RNG, can an attacker predict generated witness field elements to compromise DKG security? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-dkg/src/pcs/traits.rs] [Function: random_witness()] [Field element validation] Does random_witness() ensure generated values are valid field elements within field order, or can out-of-range values cause arithmetic errors in subsequent operations? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-dkg/src/pcs/traits.rs] [Function: random_witness()] [Distribution bias] Does random_witness() sample uniformly from the field, or can biased sampling enable statistical attacks to predict challenge values and forge proofs? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/aptos-dkg/src/pcs/traits.rs] [Function: random_witness()] [RNG state] Can an attacker manipulate RNG state between random_witness() calls to influence generated challenges and bias DKG randomness? (High)
